snippet.textDisplay: Some of my observations...the lambo is a good two feet longer than a golf and that guy is so huge he sits a good foot higher in the cab than an average guy and even he admitted he could only see the lambo in that one mirror which was spotlessly clean as well as the windscreen,he was also aware that the lambo was actually there,so an average height hgv driver with a grubby windscreen and mirror would probably not notice a car that had tried to cut in front of him(and the golf WOULD have had to have cut him up to get pushed because a lesser angle would have just smashed the side of the golf in).if you are happily driving down the road with music on and nothing in front of you why would you even check the front screen mirror that only shows about 4 feet beyond the front of your truck? I work with one excellent hgv driver that this exact same thing happened to and the reaction of the surrounding car drivers were similar to the post office incident...until a police patrol vehicle pulled up and the police had witnessed the car cutting in front of the lorry and the lorry driver was cleared of all blame.
snippet.textOriginal: Some of my observations...the lambo is a good two feet longer than a golf and that guy is so huge he sits a good foot higher in the cab than an average guy and even he admitted he could only see the lambo in that one mirror which was spotlessly clean as well as the windscreen,he was also aware that the lambo was actually there,so an average height hgv driver with a grubby windscreen and mirror would probably not notice a car that had tried to cut in front of him(and the golf WOULD have had to have cut him up to get pushed because a lesser angle would have just smashed the side of the golf in).if you are happily driving down the road with music on and nothing in front of you why would you even check the front screen mirror that only shows about 4 feet beyond the front of your truck? I work with one excellent hgv driver that this exact same thing happened to and the reaction of the surrounding car drivers were similar to the post office incident...until a police patrol vehicle pulled up and the police had witnessed the car cutting in front of the lorry and the lorry driver was cleared of all blame.

snippet.textDisplay:
This is all well and good but,

The Class 1 Tractor unit is a Next Generation Model.
The Post office was DAF with NOT THE TECHNOLOGY SHOWN in the Scania.
As a HGV driver my self.

I say if you're going to do a comparison video then do it
Like for like.
NOT with a state of the art Unit.
I will say now your video was misleading.

That Scania had the camera's and warning bleepers that not all HGVs have.
But,
Now check with the Cheshire Police department for this.
With all the cameras
All the mirror's
All the warning bleepers.
Going off and looking all around you, the road the load there is a whats called
"driver overload"
As you get flooded with so much to look at while driving it overloads the driver with too much information.
On many HGVs the side warning bleepers are turned OFF as they are going off all the time.
NOT ALL HGVs have a front facing camera.!!!.

Now please go back and do the test with an OLD BEAT UP DAF.
That you have a louder engine and no front camera's
Most Newer HGVs have a front mirror's
But,
Had THAT DAF?

If you're going to do a comparison then Please do it right.
snippet.textOriginal:

I will say now your video was misleading.

That Scania had the camera's and warning bleepers that not all HGVs have.
But,

Going off and looking all around you, the road the load there is a whats called

NOT ALL HGVs have a front facing camera.!!!.

But,
Had THAT DAF?

If you're going to do a comparison then Please do it right.

snippet.textDisplay: Firstly You have to bear in mind cameras and sensors like on this truck are optional I doubt very much that the Royal Mail truck had these fitted. Also the passenger side corner of a truck is a very bad blind spot and is very easy to collide with a car trying to cut in on that corner even with the front mirror.  by the time you’ve spotted it in that mirror you’ve already made contact at 40mph. When your in busy traffic you can’t keep glancing in that mirror every few seconds. At the end of the day as a hgv driver you can’t have eyes everywhere at the same time no matter how many mirrors or cameras fitted. The reality is car drivers should be more informed about the dangers of being around a hgv
snippet.textOriginal: Firstly You have to bear in mind cameras and sensors like on this truck are optional I doubt very much that the Royal Mail truck had these fitted. Also the passenger side corner of a truck is a very bad blind spot and is very easy to collide with a car trying to cut in on that corner even with the front mirror.  by the time you’ve spotted it in that mirror you’ve already made contact at 40mph. When your in busy traffic you can’t keep glancing in that mirror every few seconds. At the end of the day as a hgv driver you can’t have eyes everywhere at the same time no matter how many mirrors or cameras fitted. The reality is car drivers should be more informed about the dangers of being around a hgv

snippet.textDisplay: I drive this size truck for a living, and pretty much every decent truck on the road these days all have these mirrors, however and coming from personal experience, but not to the extent of this problem, a car the size of a Golf, when coming down the slip road to join a carriage way, there’s still a part on the truck that has a blind spot area, so yes it’s possible for the car and truck to make enough contact for the car then to end up sideways in front of the truck, but then the likely hood is the truck driver will be aware of the impact, and yes my truck has the mirrors and the cameras......., whether people like it or not, every driver has a responsibility to be aware of their surroundings, I drive trucks a car and a motorbike
snippet.textOriginal: I drive this size truck for a living, and pretty much every decent truck on the road these days all have these mirrors, however and coming from personal experience, but not to the extent of this problem, a car the size of a Golf, when coming down the slip road to join a carriage way, there’s still a part on the truck that has a blind spot area, so yes it’s possible for the car and truck to make enough contact for the car then to end up sideways in front of the truck, but then the likely hood is the truck driver will be aware of the impact, and yes my truck has the mirrors and the cameras......., whether people like it or not, every driver has a responsibility to be aware of their surroundings, I drive trucks a car and a motorbike

snippet.textDisplay:
So this will generate some additional views to car throttle so motive would exist to perform a stunt like this. The Ellie Golding presence also adds some questions as well. However things to consider -
1) Could the car throttle channel afford the fee she would want to appear ? I don't think so.
2) If this was a setup then royal mail will have something to say as branding a vehicle in RM livery is damaging at best.

Based on this I can only conclude that this was not staged. However it has probably had some positive impacts on the car throttle channel and profiles and no doubt ended a career for the lorry driver.
snippet.textOriginal:
So this will generate some additional views  to car throttle so motive would exist to perform a stunt like this. The Ellie Golding presence also adds some questions as well. However things to consider -
1) Could the car throttle channel afford the fee she would want to appear ? I don't think so. 
2) If this was a setup then royal mail will have something to say as branding a vehicle in RM livery is damaging at best. 

Based on this I can only conclude that this was not staged. However it has probably had some positive impacts on the car throttle channel and profiles and no doubt ended a career for the lorry driver.

snippet.textDisplay: My dad had a crash in a lorry in 09. He wasn’t wearing his seatbelt. He had a blow out on his left front tire. He swerved into a bridge concrete pillar. He flew 30 feet out the front window. If he had his seatbelt on he would’ve been crushed. 1 in a million chance that having your seatbelt off in a lorry actually saves your life. And you can obviously see Someone there. Newer cabs even brake when somethings too close

snippet.textDisplay:
I can see how it happened tbh. I'm assuming that truck was manual, and how many of us have just accidentally dropped the clutch too fast and jolted the car? Same going into 2nd, it can jolt a little bit which could hide the tiny impact of a 1.4 ton car getting pushed by something designed to tow 40 tonnes.

As for the noise of the tyres screeching, could have just had music or radio on loud.

I wouldn't jump on and start bashing him without thinking about it more, we all make mistakes.

Oh and I pride myself with always rev matching and using heel and toe so I'm a fairly smooth driver, always trying to make shifts smoother, but we all make mistakes sometimes and jolt it a little bit. So for all the raging 14 year olds about to comment saying you shift perfectly and never jolted the car and are a driving god, fuck off🙃
snippet.textOriginal:

snippet.textDisplay: I’m a HGV DRIVER OF OVER 16 years and I’ve seen this kind of thing before, go back to the video and look how low the driver is sitting in is cab, he. As got the seat so low to only can see his head from the side window, so he wouldn’t see the car and if he had Music playing the chances are they may not hear the car tires screeching as for the mirror in his front window he may not see the car , but he will feel the resistance of pushing the car making him think something is not right . It does look mad but like I said I have seen this happen before when you can collect the car in front of you and not realise it’s there until it’s too late
snippet.textOriginal: I’m a HGV DRIVER OF OVER 16 years and I’ve seen this kind of thing before, go back to the video and look how low the driver is sitting in is cab, he. It does look mad but like I said I have seen this happen before when you can collect the car in front of you and not realise it’s there until it’s too late

snippet.textDisplay: That Royal Mail lorry is a bog standard DAF 85CF. When I saw the video of the DAF the lorry only had the standard door mirrors and the kerbside. DAF lorries have a certain rumble out of them and especially an older lorry with the sound deadening wore away then it’s harder to hear the car. That Volvo looked to be the old 2008/2009 shape lorry so I’d say he couldn’t hear a thibg
snippet.textOriginal: That Royal Mail lorry is a bog standard DAF 85CF. When I saw the video of the DAF the lorry only had the standard door mirrors and the kerbside. snippet.textDisplay: This video should have been made to raise awareness not hate towards the driver,also should have shown the view from driver seat and realise that is a bit difficult to see the car.most people are mentioning the front mirror,he was driving on a 3lane road,you need to have your eyes all over the place,if he missed that mirror for  a few sec that's enough.people needs to stop relying on the other road users and assume they've been seen,it's your own life,you only have one,take good care of it.also never push in front of a truck,specially from a blind side...
snippet.textOriginal: This video should have been made to raise awareness not hate towards the driver,also should have shown the view from driver seat and realise that is a bit difficult to see the car.most people are mentioning the front mirror,he was driving on a 3lane road,you need to have your eyes all over the place,if he missed that mirror for  a few sec that's enough.people needs to stop relying on the other road users and assume they've been seen,it's your own life,you only have one,take good care of it.also never push in front of a truck,specially from a blind side...

snippet.textDisplay: Just my personal opinion. In the video the truck does have the front mirror facing downwards so he should be checking that. But you can see in the video the truck is an older model so I doubt would have a spec up to date with cameras and sensors to assist the driver. And in terms of actually using the front mirror I think it’s just a case of the driver thinking that there’s a 0.0000001% chance that there’s anything actually in front of him when he’s on a dual carriageway, which is his fault as it’s a standard procedure to do so. But in terms of CT actually having one of their guys risk their lives when there’s no clear H&S or camera crew about, I do think that it’s a bit of a bold statement.
snippet.textOriginal: Just my personal opinion. In the video the truck does have the front mirror facing downwards so he should be checking that. But you can see in the video the truck is an older model so I doubt would have a spec up to date with cameras and sensors to assist the driver. And in terms of actually using the front mirror I think it’s just a case of the driver thinking that there’s a 0.0000001% chance that there’s anything actually in front of him when he’s on a dual carriageway, which is his fault as it’s a standard procedure to do so. But in terms of CT actually having one of their guys risk their lives when there’s no clear H&S or camera crew about, I do think that it’s a bit of a bold statement.

snippet.textDisplay: Listen yan I am a hgv driver at wincanton. I drive trucks that are from 15 plates to 19 plates all trucks have all them mirrors standard. I believe in that situation you will definitely feel that car infront of you even if you aren't loaded. In my opinion that royal mail truck would of definitely had 'colition warning device' fitted which means anything near the truck would of immidialty applied the brakes. Even if you are driving the truck down the road and say a traffic cone is in the road it would lock all the brakes on the truck...

snippet.textDisplay: As an HGV driver, I was disappointed to see a lack of view from the drivers seat, if for any reason you had a broken front mirror or it was excessively dirty (ok, so you check these on your daily checks, but things happen sometimes) you will struggle to see a vehicle that close to the front of the unit, check out some of the blind spot videos on YouTube that highlight these issues. I'm not excusing the Royal Mail driver in the slighest, however unless you have ever driven an HGV you cannot understand the visibility issues particularly on older units such as the older Daf in the video (I drive an older Daf Xf without any video assistance)
snippet.textOriginal: As an HGV driver, I was disappointed to see a lack of view from the drivers seat, if for any reason you had a broken front mirror or it was excessively dirty (ok, so you check these on your daily checks, but things happen sometimes) you will struggle to see a vehicle that close to the front of the unit, check out some of the blind spot videos on YouTube that highlight these issues. I'm not excusing the Royal Mail driver in the slighest, however unless you have ever driven an HGV you cannot understand the visibility issues particularly on older units such as the older Daf in the video (I drive an older Daf Xf without any video assistance)

snippet.textDisplay: Yianni, ask Daniel if he'd risk is HGV license/job/career/business for a video stunt? The Royal Mail driver would be done for if it was a prank, possibly done for even if not.  TBH there is probably the chance that the Car Throttle Mag car took a risk and clipped it. And celebs are everywhere and human, so not that rare for them to stop (btw saw Aubameyang's Urus in Tesco's Potters Bar last week). I say it was real.

snippet.textDisplay: Speaking as an HGV driver. You’ve got over 2000nm of torque, you can push a car without there being any resistance to the truck. Although we have all these mirrors you do still have blind spots believe it or not. There’s a video on YouTube showing a view from inside the cab then they show you outside and what’s around the truck in blind spots is frightening. Please just be aware of HGVs people and if you see an HGV driver not paying full attention, please call the company on the cab and report them.
snippet.textOriginal: Speaking as an HGV driver. You’ve got over 2000nm of torque, you can push a car without there being any resistance to the truck. Although we have all these mirrors you do still have blind spots believe it or not. There’s a video on YouTube showing a view from inside the cab then they show you outside and what’s around the truck in blind spots is frightening. Please just be aware of HGVs people and if you see an HGV driver not paying full attention, please call the company on the cab and report them.

snippet.textDisplay:
"Some" lorry drivers are demented assholes that don't care for your safety, they wish to prove a point and come out on top of the situation. Being the bigger vehicle, they mostly always do.

I purchased a dashcam due to a truck driver on the motorway side swiping me on purpose. I was in middle lane, he was on left, coming out of 40mph roadworks, I'm speeding up passing him on the right side, he indicates as I reach him and immediately starts moving over slightly and slowly, I had nowhere to go as a car is approaching in third lane, didn't have time to change gear and speed out of there or brake as he hit me and carried on moving over, pushing me into the third lane. The car in third lane saw this and stopped in time.

Fucking lorry drivers need mental assessments!
